Award.AwardTitle: Metal-Free Functionalization of Electron Rich Aromatic Systems: ortho-Quinone Methides, Aza-ortho-Xylylenes, and N,N-Dialkylaniline N-Oxides in Synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor William Chain. Professor Chain is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry at the University of Delaware. He is developing new classes of reactions that that are facilitated by reversing the normal polarity and hence reactivity of molecules. Reversing the polarity means that molecules that normally behave as if they are negatively charged behave as if they are positively charged. The change facilitates the formation of a wide array of new carbon-carbon, carbon-oxygen, carbon-nitrogen, and carbon-sulfur bonds that lie at the heart of chemical structures that serve many purposes in industrial, chemical, and medical applications. Professor Chain's research group provides the highest level of education and training for students at all ages. It also offers opportunities for students typically underrepresented in science. Professor Chain is actively engaged in outreach activities in local elementary, middle, and high schools to promote science education and engagement of students in science disciplines. These activities include summer research internships in Professor Chain's laboratory for promising high school seniors. These internships encourage student interest in university studies and careers in the sciences.

An array of aromatic substitution reactions have been described since the seminal work of Charles Friedel and James Crafts in the mid to late 1800's. Despite this body of work, there are still limitations in electron-rich settings; functionalization of electron-rich aromatic systems can be controlled by virtue of a temporary inversion of reactivity. Generating and engaging highly reactive intermediates in a controlled and predictable manner by an umpolung strategy is a critical tool set in organic synthesis. Synthetic strategies in this regard are the manipulation of latent aromatic compounds and/or the temporary engagement of heteroatom-bound electron pairs and harnessing these energetic structures to form congested carbon-carbon and carbon-heteroatom bonds. This award explores two reactivity manifolds available to phenols and anilines. In the first reactivity manifold, silyl-protected phenols and anilines are converted to ortho-quinone methides (QOMs) and aza-ortho-xylylenes (AOXs). These protected species are mixed with silyl enol ethers or silyl ketene acetals to release both the electrophilic and nucleophilic participants in conjugate addition reactions by treatment with easily dispensed and handled fluoride sources. In the second reactivity manifold, anilines are oxidized to the corresponding N-oxides, which facilitates an array of bond formations that take advantage of the excision of the weak N-O bond. By virtue of these mild reaction conditions, the scope and capability of umpolung reactions with electron rich aromatic rings is expanded. The educational plan includes outreach to local elementary, middle, and high schools with integration of high school students into the research program in as research interns.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project has explored the functionalization of electron-rich aromatic alcohols and amines by virtue of a temporary inversion of reactivity. Generating and engaging highly reactive intermediates in a controlled and predictable manner by this strategy is a critical tool set in organic synthesis. Particularly powerful strategies in this regard are the manipulation of latent aromatic compounds and/or the temporary engagement of heteroatom-bound electron pairs and harnessing these energetic structures to form congested carbon–carbon bonds, carbon–heteroatom bonds, and polycyclic arrays.  During the course of the project, we continued our work to develop chemistry that leverages the reactivity of aromatic alcohols and amines that takes advantage of labile or curiously weak bonds to drive the formation of strong carbon–heteroatom and carbon–carbon bonds.  We have also begun the development of cyclization events that are critically needed synthetic tools that are useful for the synthesis of myriad important organic molecules such as catalysts, pharmaceuticals, new materials and polymers, and other useful organic small molecules.  Our new chemical processes enable simple and direct access to a wide array of complex small organic molecules.  Our work has also provided an excellent opportunity for teaching the basic techniques and skills involved in organic synthesis, synthetic planning, and the structural characterization of organic molecules to undergraduate, graduate, and high school students.  The training of students in synthetic organic chemistry by its very nature includes the essential skills of strategic thinking and problem solving, thus preparing them for any number of related fields of great importance in both the academic and the industrial arenas.   

Students of all ages undertook the project research with an emphasis placed on enabling underrepresented groups of students in the Wilmington/Newark area of northern Delaware as well as in southern Pennsylvania.  During the course of this research, we established connections with chemistry instructors at local schools for regular classroom interactions, and recruited several high school juniors and seniors for research at UD.  Our high school research participants have all contributed to and have authorship of the two published manuscripts that resulted from the project, and we have two more manuscripts that have yet been published.  All our young students have gone on to gain admission to competitive research universities and are continuing their studies by participating in STEM related research.  The graduate students involved in this research project have also received advanced degrees and have moved on to industrial chemistry positions or matriculated in other graduate studies such as patent law.   

 


Last Modified: 02/12/2021
Modified by: William J Chain
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Our project has explored the functionalization of electron-rich aromatic alcohols and amines by virtue of a temporary inversion of reactivity. Generating and engaging highly reactive intermediates in a controlled and predictable manner by this strategy is a critical tool set in organic synthesis. Particularly powerful strategies in this regard are the manipulation of latent aromatic compounds and/or the temporary engagement of heteroatom-bound electron pairs and harnessing these energetic structures to form congested carbon–carbon bonds, carbon–heteroatom bonds, and polycyclic arrays. During the course of the project, we continued our work to develop chemistry that leverages the reactivity of aromatic alcohols and amines that takes advantage of labile or curiously weak bonds to drive the formation of strong carbon–heteroatom and carbon–carbon bonds. We have also begun the development of cyclization events that are critically needed synthetic tools that are useful for the synthesis of myriad important organic molecules such as catalysts, pharmaceuticals, new materials and polymers, and other useful organic small molecules. Our new chemical processes enable simple and direct access to a wide array of complex small organic molecules. Our work has also provided an excellent opportunity for teaching the basic techniques and skills involved in organic synthesis, synthetic planning, and the structural characterization of organic molecules to undergraduate, graduate, and high school students. The training of students in synthetic organic chemistry by its very nature includes the essential skills of strategic thinking and problem solving, thus preparing them for any number of related fields of great importance in both the academic and the industrial arenas. Students of all ages undertook the project research with an emphasis placed on enabling underrepresented groups of students in the Wilmington/Newark area of northern Delaware as well as in southern Pennsylvania. During the course of this research, we established connections with chemistry instructors at local schools for regular classroom interactions, and recruited several high school juniors and seniors for research at UD. Our high school research participants have all contributed to and have authorship of the two published manuscripts that resulted from the project, and we have two more manuscripts that have yet been published. All our young students have gone on to gain admission to competitive research universities and are continuing their studies by participating in STEM related research. The graduate students involved in this research project have also received advanced degrees and have moved on to industrial chemistry positions or matriculated in other graduate studies such as patent law.
